Posts.Content: Hi I am really sorry to hear about everything happening.
Posts.Title: Mum starting chemotherapy for her2 and I'm scared about how unwell...

Posts.Content: Thanks Lynn.  Just home from work. No letter, and reminding myself it was only January to had an MRI to high so really can't imagine there is anything to report.  Decided I will ring at 3 weeks just in case.  But you are right so very comforting. Xx
Posts.Title: Annual mammogram - how long for result

Posts.Content: Hi all I have got myself in a bit of a state.  I had my first annual screen last week.  On my guidance notes it says I will hear "very quickly" if they have a cancern, but expect a result within 2 weeks.  It's 7 days in. No phone call, no letter, do you think all ok?  Back on the results anxiety treadmill.
Posts.Title: Annual mammogram - how long for result

Posts.Content: Hi Lynn I'm at st. Barts central London.  I think what has disturbed me is going back to the unit. Some of the staff recognised me.  It's a mixed clinic and there was a woman sitting behind me crying I felt so much for her, and wanted to comfort her.  It just reminds you having to go back.  I will ring at 3 weeks deffo.
Posts.Title: Annual mammogram - how long for result

Posts.Content: Thank you for everyone's replies.  comforting to know, but just does show you we have to be in control of our own health, as not getting letters etc is worrying.  x
Posts.Title: Annual mammogram - how long for result

Posts.Content: Hi Thanks to all for your replies.  It will be two weeks coming this Wednesday, so I am making an assumption there is nothing to say, but as others have said you would have thought a bit of speed given our position could be considered.  Its amazing how you go straight back to the anxiety phase waiting - brought it all back to me.  x
Posts.Title: Annual mammogram - how long for result

Posts.Content: Hi there Ansti I am 6 months post treatment and now looking back I do think there is a deliberate 'drip' of information by medical teams, I think there is just too much to take in.  It appears to me that treatment very often changes.  I was given a plan frm diagnosis day, but I realised (in hindsight) that this plan could have changed once they knew the full detail of my biopsies.  For instance I was told radiotherapy from day one, but during surgery they found a further lesion, they said I might move to chemotherapy after surgery.  As it happened  I didn't once the full biopsy came back.  I hope this helps and gives some assurance. X
Posts.Title: Surgery in 10 days, then .... no idea

Posts.Content: Hi It's so worrying at this stage and only natural that we try and second guess everything.  Agree with what has been said. Would just add and say the clinic code you mention is most likely to stand for Breast clinic (BC) and the remaining initials are likely to be the consultant surgeons initials- although that is a guess.   Breast clinics see all types if conditions.  Also, your scar is most likely radial scar, which are benign, but they like to keep an eye on them.  Hope you can get some peace while you wait.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed Today

Posts.Title: Diagnosed Today

Posts.Content: Hi all Just want to share with everyone my latest addition to my Letrozole combat.  My SE's are not too bad, but some days are better than others, with joints and muscle aches being the most debilitating side effect.  Interestingly, the SE's seem to change, i.e. gastro one week then goes - I think someone else said that.  So my current regime is:  sticking to accord brand, vigorous daily exercise, two litres of water, plus calcium + Vit D. I have now discovered sporting salt baths - I think it is epsom salts.   I bought a big bag from that chemist beginning with B and have testing this for a week - definitely a massive improvement, been having a bath in early evening - mornings are great I come down the stairs nearly normally. I have no idea if there is any real evidence behind the baths, but I am sharing anyway and would be good to know if anyone else has used!   All the best.
Posts.Title: Continuing tips in combating Letroxole SE's

Posts.Content: Hello Yellow roses I am afraid I don't have any experience as you describe, but wanted to welcome you, and let you know your post has worked! Its very interesting to hear how letrozole is working and comforting in any case so thanks posting that.
Posts.Title: Living with Letrozole, as wel as breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi. You don't have to worry about funding.  It comes under patient choice so don't be put off if you wish to change hospitals.  It isn't a second opinion, it's a change of provider.  Good luck. Xx

Posts.Content: Hi That is true for NICE guidelines, most areas have local guidelines that differ and do not have an age guideline.  Guidelines are guidelines, they can be over ruled so don't be anxious about chasing if you are worried.  Xx

Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi chloecat Hope your other health problems are improving.  I am curious to know if your oncology team still continue to offer the standard treatment.  For me this is a governance thing, I,e, it sounds like to me you could still have surgery on your breast and lymph. Idea which would give you positive outcomes.  Do your team record this offer to you  at every meetng? And I am assuming you turn this down. Just curious to be honest.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi To be honest I am really fed up with reading posts on on line public forums by women who think they know better than the research scientists. In the UK we have access to the best healthcare in the world.  If people don't want to take advantage of that then I everyone has the option of adopting their own strategy.  I would say two things.  (1). I can assure you 100% that the NHS has a huge bill treating breast cancer. If there was a cheaper way that saved lives, believe me they would be adopting those treatments.  (2). If you don't like the treatment offered you can follow through what you choose, it is your choice.  For me, I have taken the route of tried and tested treatments, in the grounds it keeps people alive.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Far too many in-accuracies in these posts for me to even attempt to respond or post something that might be reasonable and helpful.  However do dislike being potentially linked to a view that I might somehow be less intellectual because I have chosen the evidence based treatment route.  Shame
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: I'm sorry this debate is wrong and dangerous.  There is so much in-accurate information being posted here.   if this is a private thread then why is it on an open access forum?  Also  Your language of siding with each other is not very open and supportive to a fellow breast cancer sufferer is it?
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi  If this thread is a personal thread owned by chloecat  why is it not labelled as such? or put under a blog? In that way no other poor unfortunate soul will stumble in to the responses I have received (not Caroline) I disagree with your comments about blindly going into traditional NICE pathways.   A few points.  Throughout the western world where mass breast screening is undertaken, there is debate with regard to over treatment of breast cancer.  One European country has dropped mass screening due to this research, which is suggesting the treatment of low grade lesions is not improving the survival rates.  Thinking that chloecat is undertaking a one woman clinical trial which is going to benefit us all is just so really ill informed, she has her own contra health conditions. Of course I wish her and anyone else all the very best on their chosen approach, what I want to say, is be accurate in your posts, as other women, not so fortunate to have a less aggressive cancer may believe what your are posting. Lastly,  the NHS makes mistakes, private services makes mistakes, we've just locked up one breast surgeon who mainly operated out the the private sector, who really did mutilate women unnecessarily. All the best
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi there chloecat.  I am interested in what your next preferred treatment plan is.  I think you have moved forward from a stage 1 BC to stage 2 BC on your current approach, I hope I haven't got that wrong, apologies in advance if i have.  What is your recommendstion for your next steps and have you  checked out if proton therapy is suitable? Wishing you well on your house move.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Pat Welcome.   The most likely reason for a second operation is because the lump removed shows an insufficient  margin of healthy tissue.   The surgeon is guided by the scans and sometimes a guide wire, but only examination under a microscope can determine if everything has been removed, so the aim is to get a “margin” of healthy tissue around the site.  Everyone who is on the NHS BC pathway is looked after by multi disciplinary team, this includes a surgeon, nurse, oncologist, radiologist etc, they meet weekly and discuss cases and agree next best course of action, this is standard practice, so please don’t worry about that.  It’s difficult to know what decisions they will be making precisely about your relative, but the meeting is used to discuss pathology results and best treatment plan going forward. I have made an assumption here, so perhaps test gently with your relative if the above description rings bells as I would hate to have steered you in the wrong way.  Many people have a second operation, I did myself, and was much easier than the first.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Relative's Lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi This is an interesting debate.  World wide clinicians have been discussing the efficacy of treating screen detected low grade breast cancers.  When I had my diagnosis several doctor friends commented that it was down to me about how risky I wanted to be.  One European country has dropped mass population screening on the basis of research indicating that these low risk cancers can be lived with and do us no harm. I’m a scientist by background so rightly or wrongly tend to be guided by evidence and numbers, for me I went with the whole treatment plan on the grounds there is strong evidence that surgery, Radiotherapy and AIs has proved to be the most successful in eliminating re-currence.   There is another thread running at the moment discussing lifestyles etc, which is fascinating,  my conclusion on that debate is, it doesn’t matter what you eat or drink, and that was certainly the view of my oncologist.  The only thing I do think that has some strong evidence is exercise, and even if that is wrong, it’s not going to hurt you!  I do feel very strongly that alternative diets and therapies make no difference what so ever, but again I think if it helps you there is no Harm.  I take calcium with vitD even though I know clinicians think this is entirely a waste of money but I’m not going to stop. I admire you.  I couldn’t take your path, as once Pandora’s box was open for me I would have worried I had refused what had the proven evidence base for success.   What ever your choice good luck, a healthy lifestyle is always going to help no matter what. Xx
Posts.Title: Is there a risk of over treatment for early stage BC?

Posts.Content: Hi all I have been taking letrozole for 6 months now. My hair is definitely thinning which is quite distressing.  Has anyone else had this experience? And if so does it settle down in time, also is there anything I can take to try and counter balance this.  Thank you in advance.
Posts.Title: Letrozole -hair loss

Posts.Content: Shocking thread.  What I find odd is we talk about telling newly diagnosed  BC patients to only access credible sites, and not internetting Dr Google as there is so much scary information out there, and here we go with a lot of nonsense being posted.  It isn’t really fair is it? I do think there should be a separate page McMillan puts up so that people who want to discuss this stuff can do can do so at their hearts content.  So let’s be clear, lots of evidence about living healthily, eat well, exercise well, will basically keep you well.   Lots of evidence of women who have chosen alternative therapies to cure their breast cancer, I.e. drinking lemon or drinking plant based diets you will die. The point was from the original poster was to warn people away from non credible treatments, and loads of people have bowled on here and added to it.
Posts.Title: Dangerous internet information

Posts.Content: Hi Leonlaw I've just looked up the Royal College of Radiologist scoring, and here it is: 1. Normal 2. Benign 3. Indeterminate /probably benign findings 4. Findings suspicious of malignancy 5. Findings highly suspicious of malignancy If you do ever look anything up on the internet, always look at authenticated work, ie. Royal College.  So you can see that a 3 is probably benign.  xxx
Posts.Title: Indeterminate lump

Posts.Content: Hi Leonlaw Sorry you find yourself here.  Indeterminate is a radiologist grading.  They have, I think 4 grades, and it means as you have described, they are just not sure.  I had two lumps.  One was a 4 which is a definite, the other an indeterminate.  They were fairly certain it was nothing but on histology it turned out to be a grade 2 cancer.  Radiologists are brilliant clinicians but sometimes the scans just can’t show the full dimension.    I’m afraid it’s one of those things that they just can’t tell until they get the tissue under a microscope.  It doesn’t mean to say this will be the same for you, so please don’t leap to that conclusion (hard I know).  Good luck. Xxx
Posts.Title: Indeterminate lump

Posts.Content: I’m sorry I disagree with you.  We should pour scorn on some comments.  It is entirely inappropriate for people to be promoting alternative treatments on an organisation that is backed and funded by the UK government from a research perspective that does not include alternative therapies.  I think you and MCM should be much better at taking a position on this.
